page.title: 08Chatteris - Land Use Changes
page.content: Sugar beet is a very profitable root crop which was not introduced into the Fens until the 1920's. In those days it was transported by barge to be sold but now it is moved by lorry. The nearest factory is at Peterborough. Before the land was turned over to arable farming there were sheep on the Fens. Nowadays sheep are being re-introduced. They eat the beet tops which would otherwise just be ploughed back into the soil. In the summer wheat is harvested. When the stubble is burnt there are lots of fires which burn out of control. Many local people protest each year about stubble burning. Nowadays wheat is harvested by combine but in the olden days men had to work with sickles. The bailer now puts the straw into bundles making another job easier.
